selected_quotes: Universal self-charging system driven by random biomechanical energy for sustainable operation of mobile electronics
Alternative energy on the rise! A new way to create power from biomechanical sources ... like stepping.
Researchers create a high-efficient self-charging power system for sustainable operation of mobile electronics exp…
Researchers create efficient charging system for mobile electronics exploiting human biomechanics energy.

citation.abstract: Human biomechanical energy is characterized by fluctuating amplitudes and variable low frequency, and an effective utilization of such energy cannot be achieved by classical energy-harvesting technologies. Here we report a high-efficient self-charging power system for sustainable operation of mobile electronics exploiting exclusively human biomechanical energy, which consists of a high-output triboelectric nanogenerator, a power management circuit to convert the random a.c. energy to d.c. electricity at 60% efficiency, and an energy storage device. With palm tapping as the only energy source, this power unit provides a continuous d.c. electricity of 1.044 mW (7.34 W m(-3)) in a regulated and managed manner. This self-charging unit can be universally applied as a standard 'infinite-lifetime' power source for continuously driving numerous conventional electronics, such as thermometers, electrocardiograph system, pedometers, wearable watches, scientific calculators and wireless radio-frequency communication system, which indicates the immediate and broad applications in personal sensor systems and internet of things.
citation.title: A universal self-charging system driven by random biomechanical energy for sustainable operation of mobile electronics

news.title: Static electricity generator harvest 1mW | Electronics Weekly
news.summary: Called triboelectric generation, the harvester in this case relies not on rubbing, but aluminium foil being touched against a film of fluorinated ethylene propylene, then moved away again - dubbed 'contact-separation' operation.

news.title: Two-stage power management system boosts efficiency of triboelectric generators
news.summary: (Nanowerk News) A two-stage power management and storage system could dramatically improve the efficiency of triboelectric generators that harvest energy from irregular human motion such as walking, running or finger tapping.
